34.
SECTION C
Print and Industry
At first, the printed book was regarded as a cheap
manuscript. Such a small fact as the printers not putting
In page numbers for the reader is indicative. Because a
manuscript was read very slowly, it was not used as a work
of reference. A printed book could be read very fast.
It was no longer necessary, or convenient, to memorize
when reading quickly. But it became necessaiy to refer to
particular passages in a book. Yet it was a century before
such means of reference were provided by printers.
It took less time for creative writers, like Rabelais,
to grasp the new art-dimensions of printing. And Aretino
quickly discovered that the printed pamphlet could be
”the scourge of princes”. But it is not till Montaigne
and Cervantes that print comes into its o\m as a new kind
of art form. The effect of printing on industry, and
commerce, was speedy and extensive.
(a) In what sense was an exactly repeatable com¬
modity, such as printed book, a new event in
commerce?
(b) In the East to-day at a bazaar, does the
procedure of bargaining have anything to
do with the absence of exactly repeatable
commodities?
